table.description: Contains up to one row of Demographic data for each Subject combination.

column.description: Subject identifier

table.description: Contains up to one row of ICS (Intracellular Cytokine Staining) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the protein panel or protein level).
Type of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Name of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
The test article (reagent) that interacts with the specimen.
The type of test article (reagent) that interacts with the specimen.
The name of the peptide pool for which a magnitude and response call are calculated.

The name of the gene-based subpanel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the subpanel magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for the gene-based sub-panels making up the panel.
The type of specimen used in the assay. For ICS, this is generally PBMC, but may also be mucosal specimens.
The name of the marker assessed, such as IL-2 (cytokine) or Granzyme-B (protease).
The type of functional marker expressed by the ICS assay. This is usually a cytokine, but it can also include cell-surface markers, expressed proteases, and other molecules.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine.
Multiplicity-adjusted Fisher's Exact Test comparing stimulated to unstimulated cells.
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in the absence of antigen stimulation.
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in response to antigen stimulation. Adjusted for background (unstimulated) expression.
Percent of cells expressing the functional marker of interest in response to antigen stimulation.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.

table.description: Contains up to one row of ELISPOT (Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSpot) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the panel or sub-panel level).

The name of the panel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for thegene-based sub-panels making up the panel.
The type of test article (reagent) that interacts with the specimen.
The name of the peptide pool for which a magnitude and response call are calculated.

The name of the gene-based subpanel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the subpanel magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of antigens (peptide pools) for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for thegene-based sub-panels making up the panel.
A combination of protein panel and protein used for filtering.
A combination of protein panel, protein, and peptide pool used for filtering.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
Type of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Name of cell or cell subset assessed for antigen-stimulated expression of peptide(s). This cell type is usually CD4+ or CD8+ T-cells, but other cell types can also be assessed.
Indicates if the interactive part of the antigen was designed to match the immunogen in the vaccine.
The type of specimen used in the assay.
The name of the marker assessed, (IFNg, cytokine).
The type of functional marker expressed by the assay (i.e. cytokine).
Indicates if response was detected as calculated using bootstrap response call.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in response to antigen stimulation, adjusted for number of spot forming cells without antigen stimulation.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in the absence of antigen stimulation.
Mean Number of Spot-forming Cells (SFC) in response to antigen stimulation.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.

table.description: Contains up to one row of NAb (Neutralizing antibody) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
Name identifying assay
Defines the level at which the magnitude or response has been summarized (i.e. summarized at the isolate level).
The type of specimen used in the assay. For NAb assays (Ad5 and HIV), this is generally serum or plasma.
The name of the antigen.
The type of virus used in the construction of the nAb antigen.
The name of virus used in the construction of the nAb antigen.
The type of virus isolate or construct used for the nAb antigen.
The amino acid sequence inserted in the virus construct.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
A classification specific to HIV NAb assay design, in which an antigen is assessed for its ease of neutralization (1=most easily neutralized, 3=least easily neutralized)
A combination of neutralization tier, antigen clade, and virus used for filtering.
The cell line used in the assay to determine infection (lack of neutralization). Generally TZM-bl or A3R5, but can also be other cell lines or non-engineered cells.
Indicates the initial specimen dilution.
The half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50).
The 80% maximal inhibitory concentration (IC80).
Indicates if neutralization is detected.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.

table.description: Contains up to one row of BAMA (Binding Ab multiplex assay) data for each Subject/Visit combination.

column.description: Unique ID assigned to a subject for a given study.
Target study day defined for a study visit. Study days are relative to Day 0, where Day 0 is typically defined as enrollment and/or first injection.
The type of specimen used in the assay
Name identifying assay
The name of the antigen
The type of antigen used in the assay.

The name of the proteins for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. Depending on how the individual peptide pools are constructed, the protein magnitude may be the sum of the magnitudes fo the constituent peptide pools (for cases where there is no overlap between pools) or the maximum magnitude of the constituent peptide pools (for cases where the pools overlap).

The name of the panel of proteins for which a magnitude and response call are calculated. The magnitude and response calls are the maximum of the values of magnitude and response for the proteins making up the panel.
The clade (gene subtype) to which the antigen is most closely aligned. The clade may be a circulating type or a laboratory consensus or global clade.
The instrument on which the assay was performed. This affects the dynamic range of the readout, and the comparability of magnitude across instruments.

column.columnTitle: Response Call (1/0) Calculated per Response Code
column.description: An antigen-specific and frequently study-specific combination of thresholds and comparisons to baseline and reference
Indicates the initial specimen dilution.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads, adjusted for mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to non-specific (non-conjugated) beads.

Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads, adjusted for mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to non-specific (non-conjugated) beads at baseline.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of beads indicating antibody binding to antigen-conjugated beads at baseline.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to blank beads.
Mean Fluorescence Intensity of antibody-binding to blank beads at baseline.
Details regarding the provenance of the assay results.
A code indicating the lab performing the assay.
Unique ID assigned to the experiment design of the assay for tracking purposes.
